episodeTitle: Showing Off His Techniques! Zoro's Formidable One-Sword Style!
description: Zoro faces off against Monet in the Biscuit Room, utilizing his strongest one-sword technique to protect Tashigi. Meanwhile, Mocha continues running from the candy-crazed children as Chopper, Nami, and Robin intervene. Luffy struggles to escape the garbage chute while carrying an unconscious Momonosuke.

events.title: Zoro vs Monet Battle Intensifies
events.description: Zoro and Tashigi engage in combat against Monet in the Biscuit Room. Monet demonstrates her Yuki Yuki no Mi powers, creating snow constructs and blizzard attacks to overwhelm her opponents.
events.significance: This battle showcases Zoro's growth in the New World and his willingness to overcome his previous reluctance to fight women when protecting his allies.

quotes.text: I don't make promises to wild animals. They don't know any better.
quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Zoro explaining his philosophy about fighting enemies, regardless of gender

events.title: Monet's Yuki Rabi Technique
events.description: Monet uses her Yuki Rabi (Snow Rabbit) technique, creating a snow rabbit construct to attack Tashigi and Zoro with incredible speed and force.
events.significance: First demonstration of Monet's named snow techniques, showcasing the versatility of the Yuki Yuki no Mi.

events.title: Monet Nearly Breaks Tashigi's Shoulder
events.description: Monet uses her snow powers to create a powerful attack that nearly shatters Tashigi's shoulder, demonstrating the dangerous offensive capabilities of her Logia-type Devil Fruit.
events.significance: Shows the serious threat Monet poses and sets up Zoro's intervention to protect Tashigi.

events.title: Zoro's Ittoryu: Daishinkan
events.description: Zoro unleashes his most powerful one-sword style technique, Daishinkan (Great Dragon Shock), vertically bisecting Monet in a devastating attack. Crucially, he does not use Haki, allowing Monet to survive due to her Logia intangibility but leaving her paralyzed with fear.
events.significance: This is the debut of one of Zoro's most powerful techniques and demonstrates his mastery of one-sword combat. The strategic choice not to use Haki shows Zoro's intent to intimidate rather than kill, marking significant character development.

quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Zoro calling out his technique as he cuts Monet in half

events.title: Zoro's Strategic Choice to Not Use Haki
events.description: Tashigi realizes and comments that Zoro deliberately chose not to use Armament Haki when cutting Monet, which would have been fatal. This strategic restraint allows Monet to survive while demonstrating Zoro's overwhelming power.
events.significance: Reveals Zoro's growth in combat intelligence and his ability to control his power. This moment shows he can overcome his reluctance to cut women when necessary while still showing restraint.

quotes.text: He didn't use Haki... if he had, she would be dead.
quotes.speaker: Tashigi

events.title: Monet Paralyzed by Fear
events.description: After being cut in half by Zoro's Daishinkan, Monet is unable to properly reform her snow body due to overwhelming fear. She realizes Zoro could have killed her and is psychologically defeated before being physically beaten.
events.significance: Demonstrates the psychological impact of Zoro's power and intimidation tactics. This is a rare moment where a Logia user is defeated more by fear than physical damage.

events.title: Tashigi's Kiri Shigure
events.description: When Monet attempts a desperate counterattack against Zoro, Tashigi intervenes with her technique Kiri Shigure (Cutting Timely Rain), a quick-draw slash that defeats Monet decisively.
events.significance: This is the debut of Tashigi's named sword technique and her moment to prove herself as a capable swordswoman, landing the final blow against a powerful Logia user.

quotes.speaker: Tashigi
quotes.context: Tashigi executing her technique to finish Monet

events.title: Defeat of Monet
events.description: Monet is finally defeated by Tashigi's Kiri Shigure technique after being psychologically broken by Zoro's Daishinkan. The snow harpy falls, clearing the path in the Biscuit Room.
events.significance: Marks the conclusion of a major battle in the Punk Hazard arc and demonstrates the growth of both Zoro and Tashigi in the New World.

events.title: Mocha Continues to Run from Children
events.description: Mocha, having learned the truth about Caesar's experiments, continues to flee with the candy while the addicted children chase her desperately. Her sacrifice to protect the other children from the deadly NHC10 drug continues.
events.significance: Highlights the tragic consequences of Caesar's experiments on children and Mocha's heroic determination to save her friends despite their hostility.

events.title: Chopper, Nami, and Robin Aid Mocha
events.description: The Straw Hat members intervene to help Mocha protect the children from themselves, working to calm the candy-addicted children and prevent them from reaching the deadly drugs.
events.significance: Shows the Straw Hats' commitment to protecting the innocent children, even from their own drug-induced desperation.

events.title: Luffy Climbs with Momonosuke
events.description: Luffy struggles to climb out of the garbage chute while carrying the unconscious dragon-form Momonosuke on his back, showing his determination to escape and protect the young samurai.
events.significance: Demonstrates Luffy's protective nature and his perseverance even in difficult circumstances.

quotes.text: I don't make promises to wild animals. They don't know any better.
quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Explaining his willingness to fight Monet despite his previous reluctance to harm women

quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Unleashing his most powerful one-sword technique against Monet

quotes.text: He didn't use Haki... if he had, she would be dead.
quotes.speaker: Tashigi
quotes.context: Realizing Zoro deliberately held back from killing Monet

quotes.speaker: Tashigi
quotes.context: Finishing Monet with her signature technique

themes.description: The episode explores the concept of strength through Zoro's ability to defeat Monet while choosing not to kill her, demonstrating that true power includes the wisdom to know when to hold back.
themes.symbolism: Zoro cutting Monet without Haki symbolizes the difference between raw power and controlled strength.

themes.description: Mocha's continued flight from the children and the Straw Hats' intervention highlight themes of self-sacrifice and the duty to protect the innocent.
themes.symbolism: Mocha running with the candy represents bearing the burden of knowledge and sacrifice to save others.

themes.description: Both Zoro and Tashigi demonstrate their growth since the beginning of the series - Zoro in his mastery of one-sword techniques and tactical thinking, Tashigi in her ability to defeat a Logia user.
themes.symbolism: The Biscuit Room battle serves as a proving ground for both swordsmen's development in the New World.

characterSpotlights.development: Zoro demonstrates significant growth in both combat ability and tactical thinking. His use of Daishinkan and choice not to use Haki shows he has matured beyond simple overwhelming force, understanding when to show restraint while still achieving victory.
keyActions: Executes Daishinkan to cut Monet in half
Strategically chooses not to use Haki
Psychologically defeats Monet through overwhelming power display
quotes: I don't make promises to wild animals. They don't know any better.

characterSpotlights.development: Monet is revealed to be a formidable opponent with her Yuki Yuki no Mi abilities, but ultimately faces psychological defeat before physical defeat, showing that even Logia users can be overwhelmed by superior willpower and strength.
keyActions: Nearly breaks Tashigi's shoulder with snow attack
Uses Yuki Rabi and other snow techniques
Becomes paralyzed by fear after Zoro's attack
Attempts desperate counterattack before final defeat

characterSpotlights.development: Tashigi proves herself as a capable swordswoman by landing the finishing blow on Monet with her Kiri Shigure technique, showing her growth and determination to stand alongside powerful fighters.
keyActions: Defeats Monet with Kiri Shigure technique
quotes: He didn't use Haki... if he had, she would be dead.

characterSpotlights.development: Mocha continues her selfless sacrifice, running from the children she's trying to save while bearing the burden of protecting them from the deadly candy.
keyActions: Continues fleeing with candy to protect children

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime added extended scenes of Usopp discovering jarred animals in the laboratory, which was not present in the manga.
Brook and Kin'emon discovering additional kidnapped children was expanded in the anime beyond the manga's brief mention.
Animation inconsistency: Monet's body positioning after being bisected differs from the manga's depiction.
Zoro's stance when executing Daishinkan was altered from the manga for animation purposes.

trivia.fact: This episode aired on September 22, 2013, and was simulcast a day earlier on September 21, 2013 for Crunchyroll subscribers.
The episode title in Japanese is 'Ōgi Sakuretsu! Zoro Saikyō no Ittō-ryū!' (奥義炸裂!ゾロ最強の一刀流!)
Daishinkan literally translates to 'Great Dragon Shock' and is one of Zoro's most powerful one-sword techniques.
This episode marks the first time in the series that Zoro deliberately chooses not to use Haki to spare an opponent's life, showing significant character growth.
The episode contains several animation inconsistencies, including Tashigi's sword mysteriously reappearing despite being previously broken.
The episode was released on DVD on November 10, 2020, and aired on Toonami in the US on April 23, 2023.
This episode adapts manga Chapter 687, specifically pages 2-19.

sources.title: List of One Piece Episode to Chapter Conversion

trivia.fact: The opening theme 'Hands Up!' was used for episodes 591-628 in the Japanese broadcast, but was replaced with 'We Go!' for the English release due to licensing issues.
